info.game_comments:
2016 Teachers Tournament semifinal game 2.
From DAR Constitution Hall in Washington, D.C.

(1, 1).clue: An angel tells Zacharias to name his son this; "the Baptist" got added later

(2, 1).clue: The first Halloween-themed stamps issued by the USPS feature these grinning items

(3, 1).clue: Here comes this small North American rabbit of the genus Sylvilagus, hoppin' down the bunny trail

(4, 1).clue: If you guys don't know that Jess Day on "New Girl" is one of these, you'll get a demerit

(5, 1).clue: On April 22, 1957, Memphis Doors Incorporated installed the gates seen here at this performer's home

(6, 1).clue: You can look it up--Susan Wojicicki, employee No. 16 at this search engine company, rented it her garage as its early HQ

(1, 2).clue: In Matthew 14 Jesus walks on the Sea of Galilee & this disciple briefly walks out to meet him

(2, 2).clue: In February 2016, the Postal Service rang in this lunar holiday with the stamp seen here; the word "monkey" appears in Chinese

(3, 2).clue: Body of water smaller than a lake but bigger than a puddle

(4, 2).clue: On "Nashville" Connie Britton & Hayden Panettiere play competing these

(5, 2).clue: The Propylaea, a large roofed gateway, served as the entrance to the temple complex on this hill in Athens

(6, 2).clue: "iWoz: Computer Geek to Cult Icon" is the 2006 autobiography of this Apple co-founder

(1, 3).clue: The Book of Acts records that Jesus ascended unto heaven from this mount named for the trees on its slopes

(2, 3).clue: Stand & deliver the name of this man honored on a stamp & in film for teaching calculus to his inner-city students

(3, 3).clue: A wall bracket for a light

(4, 3).clue: On "Curb Your Enthusiasm", Jeff Garlin isn't Larry's agent but rather his this

(5, 3).clue: In 1989 black steel gates were installed at the entrance to this street to protect Margaret Thatcher from attack

(6, 3).clue: Bobby Murphy was a co-founder of this conversation app once known as Picaboo

(1, 4).clue: After the resurrection, Jesus appeared to this woman who at first thought he was a gardener

(2, 4).clue: This natural wonder of the Pacific Northwest, a canyon through the Cascades, is depicted here on a 2016 stamp

(3, 4).clue: Type of "reading" that alternates a line by a pastor & by the congregation

(4, 4).clue: Richard Castle on "Castle" hobnobs with the police, but is actually one of these

(5, 4).clue: To exit this compound onto Red Square, you'll have to go through the red-brick Saviour Gate

(6, 4).clue: In 2014 co-founder John Zimmer shaved the pink mustaches off the grills of its rides when it began servicing New York City

(1, 5).clue: "Greater love hath no man than this, that a man lay down his life for" these people

(3, 5).clue: To scold in a mild manner

(4, 5).clue: On "Friends" Ross was this type of scientist

(5, 5).clue: In 1870 the Portuguese built a new barrier gate at the border of China & this small colonial possession

(6, 5).clue: Marc Andreessen tweeted, "Marissa Mayer is a hero for taking on the challenge at" this.com!

(1, 1).clue: Sidley Austin of K Street can help you with this activity of making Congressmen see an issue your way

(2, 1).clue: One of the 7 Ancient Wonders, the Pharos of this Egyptian city stood on an island in its harbor

(3, 1).clue: Also starting with "T", it can mean a private teacher or be a verb meaning to act as one

(4, 1).clue: In "Heir to an Execution", Ivy Meeropol explores the truth about her grandparents, this couple, executed in 1953

(5, 1).clue: This writer of "Uncle Vanya" was the grandson of an ex-serf who had purchased his freedom

(6, 1).clue: It was the election year the photo was taken

(1, 2).clue: Try Falangetti & Weimortz for your criminal case-- they've both been on the other side as deputy these

(2, 2).clue: The Windward Point Light in Cuba stands on the grounds of this U.S. naval station

(3, 2).clue: In the U.S. military D.I. is short for "drill" this; now give me 50, you worthless lumps!

(4, 2).clue: Spike Lee's "4 Little Girls" tells of the 1963 bombing of a Baptist church in this city, claiming 4 lives

(5, 2).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reports from Lake Geneva in Switzerland.)  Lake Geneva has long been a place of literary pilgrimage; this writer called it "blue as the heavens" when she lived here with her poet husband, who almost drowned one night on the lake & did drown in Italy a few years later

(6, 2).clue: In 1976 this man beat Gerald Ford to win the White House

(1, 3).clue: A law firm as well as an individual may file a friend of the court brief, known by this Latin term

(2, 3).clue: This kingdom's 436-foot Jeddah Light overlooks the Red Sea

(3, 3).clue: Mussolini was a demagogue; an educator is this, with the same final 6 letters

(4, 3).clue: Documentaries about people with this 6-letter disorder include "Loving Lampposts" & "Normal People Scare Me"

(5, 3).clue: Gore Vidal feuded with Norman Mailer but admitted that this first Mailer book was the big one among World War II novels

(6, 3).clue: In 1984 Democratic nominee Walter Mondale chose this running mate, a historic selection

(1, 4).clue: Tops for patent litigation per U.S. News & World Report, Fish & Richardson specializes in IP, short for this

(3, 4).clue: Those spectacles & the tweed jacket make you look this adjective, meaning pertaining to a university teacher

(4, 4).clue: "The Times of Harvey Milk" is narrated by this Harvey of stage & screen

(5, 4).clue: Here's a portrait of this author as a young woman; perhaps it was painted in middle March

(6, 4).clue: In 1968 the Democrats held a riotous convention in this city

(1, 5).clue: Vince Foster was once a partner at Rose Law Firm, which claims the title of oldest in this state

(3, 5).clue: The same Latin word gives us a synonym for a building & this word for teaching that provides moral uplift

(4, 5).clue: This 1975 documentary about recluses Big & Little Edie Beale inspired an HBO movie & a Broadway musical

(5, 5).clue: Piscator teaches his friend Venator to bait a hook & catch fish in this 17th century classic

(6, 5).clue: It's the year "Smiling Bill" Taft won the White House

(0, 0).clue: Seen here in 1942 are the real-life models for this painting
